content.title: WIFI Classification for Threatened Limb
content.summary: The WIfI (Wound, Ischemia, foot Infection) classification is a staging system for patients with threatened limbs that integrates wound severity, ischemia degree, and infection status to predict amputation risk and guide treatment decisions.
content.definition: A classification system developed by the Society for Vascular Surgery that grades patients with threatened lower extremities based on three independent factors: wound severity (W), ischemia severity (I), and foot infection severity (fI), to estimate amputation risk and revascularization benefit

background.need: Existing classifications (Fontaine, Rutherford) did not adequately stratify limb salvage risk
background.validation: Multiple studies validated correlation with amputation risk

wound_grade_W.W1: Small shallow ulcer on distal leg or foot; no exposed bone; no gangrene
wound_grade_W.W2: Deeper ulcer with exposed bone, tendon, or joint; gangrene limited to digits
wound_grade_W.W3: Extensive deep ulcer or gangrene extending to forefoot or midfoot

foot_infection_grade_fI.fI1: Mild local infection; skin/subcutaneous only; cellulitis <2cm from wound
foot_infection_grade_fI.fI2: Moderate infection; cellulitis >2cm, abscess, osteomyelitis without systemic signs
foot_infection_grade_fI.fI3: Severe infection with SIRS or life-threatening infection

treatment_planning.low_ischemia: Focus on wound care, infection control

revascularization_benefit.estimated_from: Difference between wound grade and ischemia grade
revascularization_benefit.high_benefit: High ischemia grade with healable wound
revascularization_benefit.low_benefit: Low ischemia grade or unsalvageable wound

amputation_level.guides: Extent of tissue loss and infection determines amputation level
amputation_level.stage_4: May require major amputation despite revascularization

Fontaine_Rutherford.limitation: Do not incorporate infection or wound characteristics

IWGDF.overlap: Wound and infection grading similar concepts

validation.studies: Multiple cohorts demonstrate correlation with amputation-free survival
validation.limitations: Interobserver variability, especially for infection grading

definition.@value: Classification system grading threatened limbs based on Wound severity, Ischemia severity, and foot Infection severity to predict amputation risk

learning_objectives: Describe the three components of WIfI classification
Grade wounds, ischemia, and infection using WIfI criteria
Apply WIfI staging to estimate amputation risk
Use WIfI to predict revascularization benefit
clinical_pearls: WIfI = Wound + Ischemia + foot Infection (3 independent grades)
High revascularization benefit when ischemia grade exceeds wound severity
Severe infection (fI3) requires control before revascularization
More predictive of limb salvage than Fontaine/Rutherford
